div.head: Concerning the Text
div.p:
Hoc itaque vera ac pia fide Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 (I, 61, ll. 12). , etc. After the Master introduces some necessary preambles in the first distinction, here consequently he continues to the things that should be said in this second distinction which is divided into two parts. For in the first part he puts the information of those studying the Sacred Scriptures, . in the second place he continues and proves in many ways his intention. The second begins at
proponamus, ergo in medium Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 4 (I, 63, ll. 19). .

The first part is divided into three parts because in the first place he teaches how those who are studying ought to dispose themselves, in the second place he teaches which things and what sort of thins they ought to believe and suppose in order to understand it, and in the third place how they ought to proceed in this study. The second begins at
ceterum ut in primo Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 3 (I, 63, ll. 9). , and the third at
.... Non invenimus . The first could be divided in three according to the three dispositions which he asserts. For he teaches that someones studying ought to be pure and virtuous, careful and studious, calm and not quarrelsome. The second begins at
de hac ergo re Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 (I, 62, ll. 1). . The third begins at
proinde omnis qui audit Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 (I, 62, ll. 5). .

The second principal part is divided into two. In the first place he puts his conclusion or intention and proves it with the witnesses of the old law, in the second place he declare it with the witnesses of the evangelical law. The second occurs at
nunc vero ad propositum Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 4 (I, 65, ll. 24). . The first part is divided into two. In the first place he proves the simple unity of the essence, in the second place he proves the threefold difference of the persons and the eternal equality of them. The second occurs at
personarum aequalitatem Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 4 (I, 64, ll. 9). Identification is somewhat uncertain, as Lombard has "personarum quoque pluralitatem" rather than "personarum aequalitatem". . The second part now truly to the proposition at hand is divided into three parts because in the first place he shows the unity of the essence and the trinity of the three persons at the same time, in the second place he adds the duration of eternity, and in the third place he apologizes that he is not able to bring more authorities to bear on this matter. The second occurs at
ipse et necessario sui evangelii Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 5 (I, 68, ll. 3). . The third occurs at
sed quia singulae poenae syllabae novi Testamenti Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 5 (I, 68, ll. 15). . And this is the division.

div.head: Question: Whether it is able to be proved through the text of Holy Scripture that the creator of created nature is three and one.
Principal arguments
div.p: Whether it is able to be proved through the text of Holy Scripture that the creator of created nature is three and one?

It is not able to be so proved because in the first place God is not three and one, therefore etc. The antecedent is proved because no incommunicable is communicable to three things. But the Father is incommunicable and the divine essence is communicable. Therefore the Father is not the essence and consequently it is able to be argued about the Son and the Holy Spirit.

In the second place because this is not able to be proved through a false text. But the text of Scripture seems to be false or at least improper, therefore etc. Minor is clear in Habacuc 2, where it is said
the stones of the wall will cry out Habacuc 2:11 . Again Isidore valet
Why have you made us wander from your ways and you have made us to harden our harts,
so that we do not fear you?
Isiah 63:17
Again
the blind receive sight, and the lame walk Lucas 7:22 , etc. Again the Master in book 5
nothing is probable through scripture, which would have diminished faith Not found This text is not directly found in Lombard. It is possible that he means to cite the end (c. 5) of d. 2, which makes some sense. There the content is close, but the wording is different. See Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 5 (I, 68, ll. 15).
, but likewise to prove evidently the articles would diminish faith and empty it of it is value, therefore etc.

On the contrary, the Master in this distinction seems to be opposed. Again
Augustin XIV De Trinitate in chapter one says that
through the study of this science the saving faith is increased, defended, and strengthened Augustine, De Trinitate, XIV, c. 1 .

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: though this proposition, if God himself is three and one is able to be sufficiently deduced from a first principle, nevertheless that God is three and one is not able to be concluded evidently from that first principle The first part is clear because, from the contrary of the consequent, the opposite of the antecedent follows, therefore. The consequence is valid, although we do not this to be evidently valid. The antecedent is since it follows, God is not three and one, therefore God is not. For to the degree that is necessary that God is, it is to the same degree necessary that God is three and one. The second part is proved because, if it were possible to be concluded evidently from a first principle, then this would either be a priori, and this not the case because this is not possible, or a posteriori which is not the case. The latter is not the case because in the first place, since some created effect is finite, then such a proof would demonstrate that the first cause is finite. Again in the second place, though every demonstration proceeds from a created effect to a highest cause, this is insufficient because it has more dissimilarities than similarities. Further, given the fact that it might be possible for someone to be persuaded through this argument that there is a first cause, it would still in no way evidently convince them that this highest cause is triune. On this point consider the words of the Master in this distinction saying:
Non enim per creaturarum contemplationem sufficiens notitia Trinitatis potest haberi sine doctrinae vel superioris inspirationis revelatione Lombard, Sent. I, d. 3 (XXX) .

The first corollary is that many said or formable propositions about God are deducible from the first principle. This is clear from the conclusion, and this is confirmed in the case of the proposition God is not a stone because it is able to be deduced from the first principle since the opposite proposition includes a contradiction. For it follows, God is essentially a stone, therefore God is God, therefore God is intelligent, therefore God is not a stone. The first consequence is clear because the same this is predicate of itself. The second is clear because given that is necessary that God is God so it is necessary that God is intelligent. And the third is clear because no intelligent this is essentially a stone.

The second corollary: though every evidence argues for certitude, nevertheless not every certitude carries evidence. The first is clear because everyone evidently knowing a conclusion is certain about that thing. The second is clear because the fact that God is three is most certain since is believed through faith, and nevertheless we do not have evidence concerning this article of belief.

The third corollary: just as it is repugnant that there is absolutely nothing, so it is repugnant that three supposites are not really distinct. From this it further follows that the following consequence is necessary: there are not three things, therefore nothing is. This is clear because it follows, if there are not three things, then there are not three divine supposites, therefore there is no God, therefore nothing is. From this it is still inferred that it follows well, there is one, therefore there are three because there are three divine supposites. The consequence is clear because the opposite of the consequent implies the opposite of the antecedent because it follows that, there are not three things, therefore there are not three divine supposites, there is not one.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
The second conclusion: just as it is necessary in that within the divine persons there is one super simple unity of essence, so it is necessary that there is a real triune plurality or alterity. This is clear from what has been said in the first conclusion.
The is confirmed because it is in reality just as the conclusion signifies, therefore that it is so is necessary. The antecedent is clear from faith. The consequence is proved because in whatever sort of thing is intrinsecally in the divine essence, it is necessary that such a thing is. This is clear This is clear through
the Magistrum in this distinction Lombard, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 2 (I, 62, ll 15-24)
. Again through
Richard in his first book On the Trinity chapter 27 , saying
confidenter fateamur personas in divinitate secundum substantiam deitas et substantiam significare
et plures ibi personas, non plures substantias esse quia sunt plures habentes unum et indifferens esse ex differenti proprietate, unitas
Richardus De Sancto Victore, De Trinitate IV, c. 19 (183, ll. 48-52).
. This are the words
of the Master in this distinction, in the beginning
hoc itaque Lombard, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 (I, 61, ll. 1)
etc.

The first corollary: not only in the divine is there solitude or singularity or simplicity of nature, but also a true and real trinity of three equal persons. This is clear from the conclusion, whence in
John
alium paracletum dabit vobis. Iohannes 14:16 . Again in I John
tres sunt, qui testimonium dant in caelo I Iohannes 5:7 . Again Athanasius alia est persona Patris, etc.

The second corollary: though the paternal notional utterance is to produce the son equal to itself, nevertheless some speaking or understanding divine supposite is not producing the Holy Spirit. The first part is from
Augustine in his book De Trinitate
saying
Pater dicens se genuit Verbum sibi aequale per omnia; non enim integre perfecteque se dixisset si aliquid minus se vel amplius esset in eius Verbo quam in se ipso
Augustine, de Trinitate, XV, 14, 23 . The second part is proved because since a divine person understands itself and something other than itself, it follows that the Son would produce either himself or another that is not himself. Not the first since according to Augustine nothing is able to produce or generate itself, and not the second because there would thus be a quaternity in the divine, which is impossible and against the conclusion.

The third corollary: just as is necessary that there be three supposites in the divine, so it is impossible that the Holy Spirit produce something within it. This is clear from what has been said because it is true that it does not produce something internally, therefore it is necessary, therefore the opposite of this truth is impossible

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p:
The third conclusion: though the theologian through the text of scripture is not able to show evidently that God is three, nevertheless, through the same text, he his able meritoriously to sufficiently approve and deduce the Trinity. The first is clear because the object of this article is not evidently able to be deduced to the point of a contradiction, as is clear from the
first conclusion Vide supra . The second part is proved because the article is sufficiently expressed in Sacred Scripture, therefore etc. The antecedent is clear in this distinction, where the
the Master
ways
singulae pene syllabae novi testamenti hanc ineffabilem unitatis veritatem atque Trinitatis concorditer insinuant Lombard, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 (I, 62, ll. 4-5) . But that the theologian meritoriously able to inquire and to teach and deduce through scripture it is argued
from the words of Augustine
and alleged by
the Master in this distinction
Lombard, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 [n.3]
saying that
hac Trinitate nihil fructuosius invenitur Augustine, De Trinitate, I, 3, 5 (PL 42:822) . Again
the Master in his prologue
delectat nos veritas pollicentis Lombard, Sent. I, prol. [n.1], (I, 63, ll. 6-7) , namely the hope of having eternal life which was one of the moving causes for the compilation of his book.

The first corollary: No text of Sacred Scripture taken in its proper sense is false. This is opposed to what
Ockham says in hisScripto super Sententias Ockham, Sententia, XX . This is clear because otherwise the articles of faith would not be able to be proven or deduced through this text, indeed Scripture would be rendered suspect.

The second corollary: to study Sacred Scripture is a condition that increases merit. This is clear, if it is understaken in love and on account of God and is not repugnant to the catholic faith. Indeed to study in any science that has not been prohibited is meritorious, if it is commanded by a good act of the will,
as Facinus shows Facinus de Ast, XX .
The third corollary is the affirmative part of the conclusion , namely that it is able to be proven through the text of Sacred Scripture, etc. This is clear through what has been said.

div.head: Objections and responses
div.p:
Against the first conclusion it is argued: through natural reasons we are able to know and to deduce that the divine essence exists, therefore also that there is a Trinity of persons. The consequence is known because whatever is known about the divine essence truly coincides with the Trinity. The antecedent is clear through
Tullius, De natura deorum, in the second book, after the beginning ,
omnibus enim innatum est et in anima quasi insculptum esse Deo Cicero, De natura deorum, II, XX . To the same is Augustine
Augustine, Confessions, chapter 8
Augustinus, Confessiones 8, 2 (CCSL 27, 114-116) , speaking about the Platonists, where he says that with reason itself he came to the knowledge not only of the divine essence. but also of the Trinity.
The second is argued thus: every perfection found in creatures out to be attributed to God, but to generate is a perfection in creatures, therefore.

In the third place: to whatever degree nature is more actual, so it is also
more fertile. But the divine nature is infinitely in act, therefore it is of infinite fecundity.

In the fourth place: every good thing is naturaly communicative of itself. But God is an infinite good, therefore. The major is from
Dionysius On the divine names chapter 12
Pseudo-Dionysius, De divinis nominibus, XX . And the minor is in
Anselm in his Proslogion in many chapters
Anselmus, Proslogion, 2, 3, 13, 20 (I, 101-103, 110-111, 115-116) .

Against the second conclusion: if there were three persons, etc., it would follows that in the divine there is a relation and an opposition of relation, therefore it will be either only one thing or many. If only one, then there will only be two supposites or two persons. But if many, then there will be at least four supposites which is a heresy. The consequence is clear because every relative opposition requires two extremes, namely to generate to be generated, to spirate and to be spirated.

In the second place it is argued thus: God is the same in every mode in which it is better to be the same than not the same. But to be the same essentially and personally is better than not to be the same in thse ways, therefore. The major is clear through
Anselm, Monologion 15
Anselmus, Monologion 15 (I, 28-29).
. The minor is clear because it is better that what suits the Father and any person exists than not exists. But to be the same essentially and personally suits each person, therefore being the same is better than not. The minor is clear because any person is personally and essentially the same as the divine essence.

In the third place: it follows that there are three eternal divine persons, and nevertheless not all three are eternal. The consequent is implied. The consequence is clear because through the conclusion and its corollary there are three coeternal persons, and they are alos eternal. But that there are not three eternal things is clear through Athansius who says
there are not three eternal things but one Athanasius, XX .

In the fourth place against the second corollary: if through understanding, etc., then it follows that any person will produce the Son. The consequence is clear because everyone understands something, therefore it follows that this person produces himself or something other than himself through understanding or loving. This is confirmed because, if the Trinity of persons is compatible with simplicity, by the same reasons it is compatible with quaternity because there does not seem to be a reason why the Son is not able to produce the son through his own understanding just as the Father.

Against the third conclusion: that God is three is nowhere expressly found in Sacred Scripture, therefore. The antecedent is proved since, because Scripture has many senses and understandings, it would be possible for and adversary to say that Christ and others who are speaking about the Trinity were not speaking literally, but mystically and figuratively.

Against the first corollary because there are many propositions which appear to false in the literal sense, but this is the proper sense of Scripture, therefore. The antecedent is clear in
John 10
ubi Christus dicit
I am the gate Iohannes 10:9 . Again,
I am the true wine Iohannes 15:1 . This is confirmed because the doctors of the scripture contradict themselves, therefore. The antecedent is clear from
Augustine Augustine, XX
and from
Jerome Super epistola Pauli ad Galatas in many passages Jerome, XX . Again, the antecedent is confirmed because the Gospel authors seem to disagree among themselves. This is clear because, on account of this matter, Augustine seems to have written his book On the harmony of the Gospels.

Again, against the conclusion and the second corollary: since the ones studying theology expose themselves to the danger of erring, therefore no one ought to study theology, nor is the study of theology meritorious. The antecedent is clear because within this study are mixed in the words of the philosophers and heretics which are neither licit nor helpful to read in their own right, as is clear from Jerome, who was seriously wounded by the fact that he read the books Cicero as it his said in his legend.

Again, through the study of theology the habit of believing is easily acquired, therefore through this study the one studying loses a circumstances that increases merit. The antecedent is clear. And the consequence is proved because the difficulty of believing is a circumstances that increases merit, whence
Jerome in some epistle
says
what is of greater merit is that which is of greater labor Jerome, Exhortatio ad sponsam Christi, XX . Again
Ambrose in his book On Cain and Abel
says,
all virtue consists in labor Ambrose, De Cain et Abel, XX .

the Philosopher in book II of the Ethics Aristotle, Ethics, II, XXX
seems to support the same point, from which it seems to follow that it would be better to have the status of a simple
faithful pilgrim than that of a profound or subtle doctor.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first: whatever is the case concerning the antecedent, the consequence is denied. For the proof it is said that the divine trinity is known by some and not known by some.

With respect to the saying of Augustine about the Platonists: in the first place it is said that Augustine does not say that he himself found this in the book of the Platonists, but in of some Platonist. But there were many Platonists after the coming of Christ, like Porphyry, Plotinus, et Apuleius, who were perhaps good men. In the second place it is able to be said that if someone had known about the Trinity, they would have had this from divine inspiration, just as Secundo potest dici quod si aliquid noviter de Trinitate hanc habuerit ex divina inspiratione, sicut dicit
Augustine says in hermete Mercurii in the sermon Contra quinque haereses
Augustine, Adv. Quinq. Haer. III, 1-21 (CCM 60, 264-268)
.

With respect to the second: in the first place the major would be able to be denied because to merit or to be able to merit is a perfection in creature, nevertheless it is not able to be attributed to God. In the second place, the minor would be able to be denied because perhaps to generate or to be able to generate is an absolute perfection most especially in the divine because, according to what is commonly argued, since the Son is not able to lack any perfection.

With respect to the third consequent would be able to be conceded because the divine nature in the supposites of the Father and the Son is of an infinite fecundity since the Father produces the Son in every way equal to himself, and the Father and the Son produce the holy spirit consubstantial to themselves.

The fourth: the entire argument is conceded and yet from this it is not evidently concluded that a Trinity of persons is in the divine. Indeed it could be equally proved through this means a quaternity and quinternity, perhaps even more than a trinity.

To another argument: the minor would be able to be denied and for the proof it is said that, though some person is of the same essence personally and essentially, nevertheless it is not the case that same thing suits all three persons personally at the same time. Again, it is able to be said that this major premise, in which it is said it is better that what suits the Father or any person exists than not exist, is true if it is not relative but is only including a relation.

To the third argument: it is said that the eternal or eternal things are able to exist substantively, and thus are not three eternal things but one eternal thing, or adjectively and thus there are able to be called there eternal or eternal things. In the second place, it would be able to be said that it is more properly said that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are coeternal than eternal, therefore Athansius concedes the first and denies the second.

To the fourth: the consequence is denied and for the proof it is said according to Thomas of Argentina, in the second distinction of the first book, in the first article,
that it is said is taken in two ways when applied to the divine.
In one mode properly, and in this case it is the same things as grasping the world. And it is in this manner that
Augustine VII De Trinitate
Augustine, De Trinitate, VII, xxx
uses the word when he says that no one but the Father is speaking internally. In another mode the word to say is take to mean to understand perfectly,
and thus any person speaks itself, and in the same way it could be said about the word to understand. It is in this way that
Anselm, in the Monologion, 57 et 59 chapters
Anselm, Monologion 57 and 59 (I, 68-70)
uses the term when he says individual persons speak themselves any of them speak themselves. But if an evident reason is sought for why the Son does not produce the Son through his speaking just as in the case of the Father, it is able to be said with
Anselm, Monologion, 85o et 68o capitulis Anselm, Monologion, non invenimus , that this transcends every act of human understanding. Through the same, the response to the confirmation is clear when it is said by the same reason etc. The consequence is denied, and when it is said because the argument does not seem, etc., it is said that, though we know this properly but not perfectly, nevertheless there is something to it, and therefore through believing we ought to take the intellect captive.

To the first against the third conclusion: the antecedent is denied, for it is clear in
Matthew in the last chapter Matthaeus, xxx ,
John in chapter 1 Iohannes, xxx , and also in the
in Decretals of the Roman Pontiffs Decreti Romanorum Pontificum, xxx , in which, whoever would contradict, would be censured as a heretic. Nevertheless I do not want to say that the Decreta are Sacred Scripture. quibus, qui contradiceret, censeretur haereticus. Nolo tamen dicere illa decreta esse Scriptura Sacra.

To the second: in the first place the antecedent woudl be able to be denied, when speaking about propositions which are put in the the text of Sacred scripture not only narratively, but also assertively. In the second place for clarity, note that the proper sense of any scripture is the sense that the author Scripture intended by it. This is shown by
Armacanus, in book one De quaestionibus Armenorum, in the beginning of this book.
Richard FitzRalph, De quaestionibus Armenorum, xxx .

In the second place, note that, since Scripture has many senses, if the truth of some text is not able to be maintained according tone one sense, one should run to another with which the other Scriptures better harmonize. And the highest care should be taken that the figurative expression is not admitted to the literal expression, and conversely that the true and proper expression is not changed into a figure and through to be figurative.

In the third place, it should be noted that, though through scripture something can be signified through a likeness, nevertheless it is not necessary on account of this that the same thing in one place signifies one thing through this same word through a likeness. This notable is asserted by
Augustine III De doctrina Christiana Augustine, De doctrina Christiana, III, xxx
and he offers an example about everything.

To the confirmation, it is said that doctors are not authors of Sacred Scripture, but only expositors. Concerning the evangelists it is said that in no passage are they really discordant. And accordingly his book is not called on the discord but on the concord of the evangelists. Nevertheless if it were called on the discord, this would not be true and real, but only an assessment or an opinion and mere words.

To another: the antecedent is denied, if one studies in the way they ought. For such a person ought not to seek to understand in order to believe, but
believe in order to understand Anselm, Prosologion, 1, (I, 100, ll. 18-19)
as
Anselm says at the end of the prologue of his Proslogion . To the proof concerning the sayings of the heretics, etc., it is said that reading such words is licit when it is for the learning of what is true and the rebuke of what is false. But such reading is not licit when it is for the purpose of believe or imitation or the vanity of assertion or the inordinate delight. And perhaps therefore Jerome was flogged and beaten because he was reading with delight since perhaps on account of that love he was missing the better and more useful parts.

To the last: it is said that, though the one studying believes more easily, nevertheless his merit does not diminish on account of this because in this case he acquires better things, such as to believe more intensely or extensively, more expressly or more truly. For through a habit of this type he subordinates faith to his love and actually directs it into God. .

In the second place it would be able to be responded by denying the antecedent because the more subtile theologian does not always believe more easily, indeed many arguments and objections arise for the theologian that do not bother the simple believer.

From what has been said it is clear that it does not follow from these things that through the study of theology there is acquired, with respect to the articles, a knowledge superior to faith. Therefore the same thing is evident and inevident, evident through science, inevident through faith. But it follows that one assents to an article through some means that does not come from scientific evidence.

The first argument to the contrary: in the first place it would be possible to say that when taking communicable as communicated to another, it is distinct from the one to whom it is communicated. In this way it is said that the essence is not properly communicable.

In the second place, it is said, by following the common school and the mode of speaking of the doctors, that the essence is communicable and not the person. And then the major premise is able to be understood in two ways. In one mode nothing incommunicable is communicable to three things, that is, it is not something which is communicated to three things, and thus the major premise is false. In another mode nothing incommunicable , that is, this is not able to be communicated to three things, and then the major premise is true, but form of arguing is not valid.
To the other two it is clear through what has been said what should be responded.

div.head: Conclusiones pro secunda distinctione
div.p:
Hic itaque vera Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 2, c. 1 (I, 61, ll. 12).
this second distinction contains three final sentential conclusions. The first: that the Trinity of divine persons is the only one and true God.

The second conclusion: that in God is a unity of essence or substance and a trinity of persons. Therefore there are not three gods but one God, though the Father generated the Son, and therefore the Son is not the who is the Father, and the Son is generated from the father, therefore the Father is not who the Son is, and the Holy Spirit is not the Father nor the Son, but the spirit
is only coequal and consubstantial to both Father and the Son. Nor in this case are they different neutrally, rather they are different personally.

Third conclusion: that ever catholic writer who has written about the Trinity which is God intends to teach that the Father and Son and Holy Spirit are of one substance and essence and are one God with an inseparable equality. And this unity in essence and trinity in persons is proved through many scriptures and in many testimonies of holy doctors. Moreover the Master ads near the beginning of this distinction that this highest good, namely God the Trinity, is only recognized by minds purged through faith. And this concludes this distinction.
